review_title: Neighborhood Assistance Corporation of America, NSR
pros: I have the opportunity to truly help people where they are in every aspect of the process. In the very beginning of the process, I am at the Home Buyers Workshops walking Closed members on the stage to share their testimony to the new members about how NACA helped them achieve their dream of homeownership. I help new members get their NACA ID Numbers at the workshops so they can start their process. In the office I am able to share my personal testimony with members about how NACA advocated for my own dream of homeownership. I have the opportunity to explain the importance of the documentation and how it helps the counselor advocate on the behalf of the members. And when it's all over I am there on closing day to see the once new member close. BUT WAIT: It doesn't end there because then, those once new members who have now closed, walk with me on the stage to share their experience of achieving their dream of homeownership with the newest NACA members.
cons: I work weekends and some holidays depending on the need of the community, but the bosses are fair and honor loyalty.

job_title: Home Save Mortgage Counselor in Charlotte, NC
pros: The traveling out of state is cool sometimes.
cons: They told you last minute sometimes that you had to travel out of state. The staff is a mess and full of drama. Pay isn’t great.

review_title: Working at the Neighborhood Assistance Corporation of America
pros: NACA is a fast-paced environment. where you engage your clients AKA members on a daily basis navigating them through the property qualification process which leads to the next step which is home ownership.
cons: At times a buyer's lack of understanding the process and time constraints causes delays and their frustration. At times I need to revert to some basic training steps so buyers and staff can help the buyer understand the process.

pros: I have the opportunity to help people who are in need. I have a good relationship with my managers and coworkers, whom are very considerate and supportive.
cons: The hours can be sporadic. There are times where the rules and regulations are inconsistent. One person will say “a”, another will say “b” and another will say “c”. Not entirely uniform.

pros: The training with NACA is awesome, it's detailed and geared towards helping you succeed. The training teams are knowledgeable, experienced and supportive. They spend an adequate amount of time with you to make sure that you understand what your role is and that you flourish in it as you grow in experience.
cons: Training start times on the west coast. Course materials used to study for MLO exam- maybe look at another company to help new hires who need to take the exam to prepare a bit more.

job_title: National Service Representative in San Antonio, TX
pros: NACA is an organization that brings the dream of home ownership to communities at large and stands as a barrier between "weaponized" lending practices. We want our members to succeed and become homeowners, to create and better communities nationally for those most in need.
cons: We are a national company which can sometimes be confusing for our members calling from one region of the country and expecting the staff that they get into contact with to be in the same region.

review_title: Good job for a single person
job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in Roxbury, MA
pros: Pretty much unlimited OT Great mission to help individuals build wealth through homeownership. Definately the number 1 mortgage in America.
cons: Do the demands of the business and the CEO, Mr. Marks - there is not a healthy work - life balance. For smart, experienced employees that can offer ideas … Mr. Marks does not even listen to new ideas- he shuts suggestions done almost immediately.…. One has to work withoout exception “in his box”

job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in Newark, NJ
pros: You get to meet with motivated clients, and the stream of clients never ends, they send too many your way.
cons: They overwork you, you work alot to make very little compenation, not much more than minimum wage. The systems are slow and outdated. You get paid mostly on commission but they give you no freedom in making your own choices and are constantly overwhelmed with meeting with new clients, you don't have time to complete past clients. They speed through training so you get thrown in without knowing what your are doing so you are forced to learn everything on the job while you are working on active files!

review_title: Great place to work and help others achieve their dream of homeownership!
pros: Working with members to become homeowners. Being a part of such a great milestone in the life of individuals is a blessing. Teaching them to better handle their finances and preparing them for being successful in not just getting a home but keeping it and building generational wealth. Also love that I don't have to worry about Leads.
cons: Moving performance targets that can negatively impact pay.

review_title: Great Product, Low Salary, Heartless HR & Aggressively Mean Mentorship Program
pros: 1. My co-workers in my local office and my training cohort were so supportive 2. The mission of this company is inspiring 3. You have the opportunity to get certified as a HUD counselor and NMLS training (Well Organized) 4. Great product! Therefore utilize the NACA mortgage, but do NOT work here!
cons: 1. Too many roles for $15/hr, housing counselor, financial planner, loan processor, etc. 2. Inhumane Tickler on the computer must be addressed if you go to the bathroom, grab a cup of coffee, consult a colleague, etc. Make you feel like we are working in the 80s as a low wage worker. Hire employees that you can trust. 3. Leadership has no idea how terrible HR and the Training Department treat new employees. 4. Everyone trains on zoom for 3 months in Eastern Standard Time Zone which is a total disregard for employees need to maintain work life balance, family responsibilities and safety in other time zones.

job_title: Rehab Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: Good Company to work with that has a mission to help family achieve the homeowner ship dream. Really enjoy working with the diversity of people within the company and members.
cons: Evaluation for pay increase are not always consistent in order to keep up with the cost increase of the economy.

pros: No need to market yourself; pipeline is guaranteed. Management assistance at your fingertips throughout your workday. Co-workers are amazing. Satisfying feeling when you are assisting families to get into their homes that they may not have been able to with other lenders. I fully support our mission to help the low to moderate income family become homeowners and kickstart their generational wealth.
cons: Long hours. Two work Saturdays per month for Homebuyer Workshops; which are mandatory workdays even if not assigned to do the workshop that day. Events throughout the year that require even longer hours. Would not be a good fit for anyone with small children.

pros: Some of the pros for NACA is that we don't just get you into a mortgage, we counsel you into an affordable mortgage. We qualify you based on the amount you can afford and not on just the purchase price, making it easy for your home to be in your family for generations. We literally meet the members where they are at, financially, mentally and even emotionally and we walk them to the closing table. The energy you feel when you get the member qualified for homeownership is priceless.
cons: There is no perfect work place and there's always room for growth and change.

job_title: Post-Close Manager in San Antonio, TX
pros: Fast-paced enviroment, no day is ever the same, very rewarding assisting first time homeowners with their financial and construction needs. Great Benefits, Fellow employees are wonderful, Management is caring
cons: More than 40 hour week

pros: Each day I come to work, I'm proud to be a part of an organization that literally helps change the lives our our members, their families, and the communities they live in. No two days are the same and you're constantly interacting with different members every day to assist them on their journey to homeownership. I was once told that if you love what you do, you'll never work a day in your life - - and now I understand what that means.
cons: No job is perfect and every job or position will have it's challenges. And working for NACA is no different. But I guess the biggest challenge for me I would say is the negativity that the very members you are trying to help can sometimes be unwilling to change their mindset or poor financial habits. So that's when it's difficult, because you can only lead a horse to water, but you can't make them drink

pros: You are looked at as an asset to the community and provide knowledge and assistance to people in your community to help them achieve their goals of Homeownership. Every experience with a member is one to remember whether it be a lesson or the blessing of watching someone complete the program and achieve Homeownership. Company is like Family and the people are here for the right reasons.
cons: Work/ Life balance is off and base salary is lower than it should be for the tasks performed by the counselors/ originators.

We have The  Best communication in a multi office business that I’ve seen. Though we are spread apart all over the country, we have weekly and monthly meetings so no employee is on their own. We also have a department that deals with assisting employees with new and specific problems. I’ve never worked for a company so effective before NACA.

review_title: Everyday, Ordinary People Doing Extraordinary Work!
job_title: Licensed Mortgage Loan Originator in Las Vegas, NV
pros:
A great company with an awesome mission! NACA is simply an inspiring place to work. 

The management here is respectful, smart, and extremely encouraging. They really want you to BE your best self which I've not experienced at a job before. They exhibit the leadership needed to encourage entrepreneurship and they help you to hone your vision and guide you through execution. 

The coworkers here are beautifully diverse and super amazing. I've met some brilliant people here. And someone is always extending a helping hand or some knowledge to make the tasks and job more understandable and easier.

I found that I'm even more invested in my work because it speaks to my beliefs about economic justice. Helping those who have been marginalized find homeownership is fulfilling work. And helping ANYONE with a purchase of a home makes me feel purposeful. 

It's a motivating company culture all around - very stimulating and energizing. There is a National Meeting monthly and I'm always in awe at these ordinary people doing extraordinary work. And I'm proud to be one of them!
cons: I really can't think of any cons at the moment. There are very long hours but mostly it's by choice. I find that many here will work overtime and weekends because we're self-driven to complete tasks and exceed Member expectations.

pros: Predicated on global working exposure and experience, NACA is definitely one of the best establishments to be engaged with as an employee. The passion, zeal and commitment to excellence in pursuit of the corporate mission of 'fighting for economic justice through comprehensive counseling with access to NACA's Best in America Mortgage' as personified by the CEO, Bruce Marks, is amazing. I am most fortunate to be deployed at the Washington, DC Office, where the Office Director, Djuro Mircetic, an astute professional, has enabled an awesome family and dedicated working environment. And the impeccable training afforded me the opportunity to secure both the HUD Counseling and Mortgage Originator certifications within a month.
cons: Yet to be identified or experienced.

review_title: NACA is Not a just a Job, It’s a LIFESTYLE with an Awesome Mission!
pros: The ability to counsel and help low to moderate income people realize their dreams of homeownership. It’s an amazing feeling when you help someone who didn’t think homeownership was even a possibility, let alone a reality. NACA provides the platform and resources to educate and help others while learning and elevating yourself in all things related to housing, mortgage, and neighborhood stability, just to name a few. NACA provides a great benefit package with excellent healthcare coverage.
cons: Most people complain about the hours and I don’t mind the hours because the work that I do is rewarding and fulfilling but it comes with a fair amount of stress for the low wages. You have the ability to earn a higher income but it is CONTINGENT on everyone finding and closing on their homes. I don’t have a problem with the commissions but the hourly wages are not competitive enough and to have your wages reduced when becoming a licensed MC is quite disheartening. I knew this coming onboard with NACA, therefore I wasn’t blind sided. If I could have a few major changes, it would be an increase in my hourly pay and a little more flexibility and voice with my calendar management.

review_title: Career that Allows Me to Add Value to Lives Daily
job_title: Internal Staff Support Manager in New Orleans, LA
pros:
The Pro for me is that I have been able to work for NACA and work for my community. To help others realize that homeownership isn't some dream for a select few, but there is a mortgage product that levels the playing field. I have been able to learn from the best, Mr. Bruce Marks our CEO and Mrs. Pam Brooks. I have worked for NACA for now 20 + years. I could not see myself working for anyone else. To be able to add value through coaching/training, educating the masses to how they can become a homeowner has been the absolute best. Now I have the honor to be a support to our staff nationwide helping them move their members file through the process. 

If you are looking for a career in the mortgage industry, looking for a company that will educate, train, and a team that is dedicated to your success, and career growth. Look no further than NACA!
cons: That people still believe our mortgage product is too good to be true!

review_title: Changing Families One House at a Time
pros:
Working at NACA is truly a purposeful job. I feel so thankful, honored and blessed to work for a Company that is truly changing the lives of families for this generation and those to come. At NACA we relentlessly work to ensure that our members are able to become Homeowners and to do so without the added burdens that other lenders do. No closing costs, no PMI, no down payment, no application fees, no points to name of few our benefits. But what is truly amazing is that I can to help people of all walks of life, all nationalities, all types of backgrounds achieve their dream of homeowner. NACA is the stepping stone, the milestone, the foundation for not only homeownership but for generational wealth for the families we assist and their loved ones. At NACA we counsel and teach our members the importance for financial stewardship, exercising your voice in matters that affect your community. We empower our members to have confidence, security, and build their wealth through Homeownership. NACA is truly in a class of its own. We are building, rebuilding not only communities but families and spirits up.

I applied to get my foot on the door with the mortgage industry. First, they said they will pay between $15 to $18 dollars an hour, I thought me having more than 10 years of experience in customer service and a bachelor's degree in office Administration I will be put as $18. After calling over and over to HR to ask for the status they finally interviewed me and offer me the position for $15 I told them this was unacceptable since I was making $19 with AT&T and they told me everyone start at $15 and she was going to negotiate so the next day they offer me $16 ,because I was desperate to get out of the call center I accepted.

First, you have no training I was given informal training for 2 DAYS to get used to the system and throw into the position. In NACA you will be the dealing primarily with people of color (Employees and Customers). which I don’t have a problem with to be clear, since I’m Hispanic and black but most of these people are ghetto and don’t know the way to professionally behave in a work environment 

I was yelled at by one of the counselors for telling her that she was missing customer appointments and that was unacceptable as well as bringing family members to the office when we were closed to the public. I was also yelled at by one of the realtors for telling him to not remove the mask while inside the office I reported the incident to HR and my manager and nothing was done.

Out of the blue, the CEO had a meeting with us and he wanted to turn the administrative assistance role to a call center role  from one day to the other with no training and no opportunity to do anything else. THEY HAVE PREFERENCE FOR CERTAIN PEOPLE, so those people were immediately moved out of the administrative assistant position into something else, I told them that I wanted to be moved since I quit my previous job doing $19  they give me the run around mind you that I grow out of the position also immediately and my local manager was very happy with my performance and the way I was managing the office 

HR TOLD ME (Saffron) to applied for the position so I thought I was going to be given the opportunity to be moved, I received another email for an interview on a Saturday uncompensated for the interview (most companies will interview you during business hours) i join the meeting and after a hour waiting they drop the call, i call my regional manager and told them what was happening and he told me will reach out so they can interview me. Another lady call me from HR and told me that i can’t be interview because i need to have 6 months or experience with them. That is completely lies since they hire people from the street for the housing counseling position and most them quit before getting to the office because they realize what a horrible company NACA is.

They already have try to implement the new role of call center so you have the phone ringing back to back and random people telling them that they are in charge one of them kimberly worthy was micromanaging me and when i call her out she told me and I quoted “excuseeee me I’m not micromanaging you yet” so i also reported this situation to HR 

I missed work Monday and Tuesday because I was very upset with they Interview since they basically play with me.I was not answering the calls because obviously i was catching up with my emails and the customers request. I was handling a situation with one of the customer that needed spanish assistance and going over the document with him and because I put my Skype as do not disturb this lady the same as before send me a email stating that i needed to be available and if i can’t comply to let her know obviously I couldn’t see the email since i was using my two screens. When I finished i saw the email and reply suddenly i received a call from HR (saffron) again telling me about the Skype i told her what i was doing she told me it doesn’t matter we are moving to terminate you.

Let’s talk about the customer, NACA  is for people who will not get approved anywhere else, therefore be ready to deal with people trying to cheat their way into the program meaning having horrible credit score, no money, no financial responsibility ,no education, horrible financial habits like bank account with overdraft and nsf fees (basically they want you to teach them how responsibility looks like). They have a Facebook group where people
Will comment everything that happen with them at naca and also they will post your personal information online like your full name and corporate email address so
For me that I’m very private and don’t like my personal information online is a huge red flag. Also they said that doing noise or escalating your case will get you approve, so you get people trying to do just that.

counselors without license $15 and people with license $10 plus commissions so they focused on people who they can help and can close the loan and pretty much ignored a lot of other people, they are constantly missing members appointments

review_title: Being Apart of The NACA Family
pros: I’ve been with NACA now 3 and a half years. I started off as an Admin and worked my way up to becoming a Housing Counselor and soon Mortgage Counselor. There is room for growth and advancement. I am apart of the Jackson, MS office and I couldn’t ask for a better team! From our current admin Zena, other counselors, extended NACA family and my our Regional Shawn Cunningham this work experience has been so memorable. We have weekly training to ensure we are always performing at our best ALWAYS. Monthly calls with our CEO Bruce Marks so he can stay connected with his staff. A list long senior employees at our finger tips to assist us anytime we need help/ assistance. So many different and helpful ways to ensure continue educations/ trainings that allows you to be better at your job. I love that! We simply are like a family, so saying “NACA family,” truly means FAMILY! Before COVID we traveled many times doing events. Having the opportunity to meet team members from other states and members from all over. Being able to be apart of helping others achieve the dream of homeownership is something I never dreamed of doing. However, now I can’t see myself not being apart of the change. Overall, I am happy to be apart such a positive, meaningful, helpful and most important NECESSARY MISSION! Time well worth the invest. Great opportunity! I’m grateful!
cons: There are SO MANY good things I can say about being apart of this great organization. As far as cons go, being apart of the NACA family you will work long hours some days. Sometimes 7 or 6 days week. Although the days/ hours/ weeks can be long and sometimes feeling exhausted, it’s well worth it knowing the purpose!

job_title: Housing Counselor (HUD Certified) in Chicago, IL
pros: I love that I get to go to work and help people everyday. Of course it's not as important as a doctor or police officer saving lives each day, but I do feel that the work we do at NACA is definitely helping to change peoples lives for the better. On a daily basis, I have the privilege of helping low to moderate income families purchase their first home - many of whom are the first to own a home in their entire family (sometimes the first in several generations!) I especially feel good about my job, because I know that not only do we help people get mortgages that otherwise could not, but we also counsel them so that they know how to keep their home and many times even improve their credit and overall financial status by the time they complete the program and receive their mortgage. We have a less than 1% foreclosure rate out of all the hundreds & thousands of NACA mortgages to our members - - so that's probably the best part for me, because I can sleep well knowing that we really do offer the best mortgage in America!
cons: It would be really great if there were instructional videos or YouTube tutorials available that counselors could send to members to show them how to submit their financial documents (paystubs, tax returns, bank statements, etc) through the NACA web file portal that every member receives to go through the application process.

pros: Tons of overtime and no micromanagement.

pros: There is no pros in this company
cons: Everything is a con in this company

pros:

- NACA has the best purchase product in the market. There are no down payment, no closing cost , no fees, no requirement for perfect credit ( Which should Excite Anyone), and it's below-market interest rate.

-The interest rate buying power is best purchase options, available to anyone interested, in the lowest possible principle and interest payments.

NACA has many of pros about its history, direction and what it stands for.
cons:
Angry members 

Long bus rides ( Must be physical and mentally healthly) 

Hours often changes ( must be flexible) 

Counseling is critical and the most important part of the service NACA’s offer. Some session may be longer than expected. This happens often due to a language barriers, unnecessary verbal communication, helping a member with budget expense , correcting a profit and loss statement and being the educator. Members come to the program for help and it’s new to them, so the know become the students.

pros: There are a lot of pros for this job. Meeting new people that need their right to homeownership solidified with a resource, a work environment that is relaxed and the administration does not use intimidation tactics to have the employees be compliant, the satisfaction of helping a stranger with the most important purchase of their lifetime and knowing that the product your bestowing is the absolute best in existence, supportive staff, clean relaxed work environments even during touring the country for registration events, the knowledge of knowing that the CEO/Founder is not capitalistically motivated, and most of all, my happiness is hinged on how many people that I can help at a job like this. I can help one in ten people that I casually meet and more.
cons: I have had to study a lot of material to maintain the standard that the company wants. Having had no real estate experience prior to coming here I thought I would be far behind but I'm not. It was a perception. As long as a new hire can take a deep breath and not allow their perception of company expectation drive them up a wall, one will discover that the pressure is not as hard and heavy as it seems.

review_title: The WORST Company to Work For

review_title: Great Place To Work And Grow Professionally
pros: I have being working at NACA for 9 years and every year, the company has grown and taken the initiative to develop ways to improve so that It can continue to provide life changing services to the people. I was a mortgage and real estate professional prior to coming to NACA but this company has enhance my knowledge about the mortgage industry and afforded me the opportunity to grow professional based on diligence, work ethic and performance. The environment is conducive to learning and your growth is dependent on the ceiling that you set for yourself. If you are motivated to do great things for your community and see the rewards of your labor, this is the place to work. Opportunity is truly based on merit and you will be mentally stimulated and challenged to continue to self actualize everyday.
cons: NACA is an advocacy organization in addition to being a mortgage broker. Advocacy is not for everyone. The hours can be long depending on your position but the day goes by fast. pros: Lot of opportunity working for NACA

pros:
I have worked with NACA for 6 years and have never once regretted my decision to work for this amazing organization. The work that NACA does to help people purchase homes that would never be able to do so with a traditional lender, and with the absolutely best terms and lowest interest rates in the country is the reason that I continue to do the work that I do with NACA. Knowing that I have been able to help thousands of people achieve the American Dream of owing their own home is priceless. Starting out as a Mortgage Consultant and being promoted to management has been a challenging but worthwhile journey and I have grown personally and professionally from my time with NACA. 

I would encourage anyone that has a desire to help others achieve the American Dream to apply.
cons: I do work long hours and am trying to achieve a better work/life balance however when you love what you do it doesn't feel like work. Being a non Profit organization they don't always have the most up to date computer equipment, however they are working on upgrades

pros: Very dynamic environment, a very supporting team, tools and training provided to succeed, the pipeline is provided to you as NACA is a membership organization with a unique mortgage product and concept, the pay is very competitive with incentives to make a six figure income for meeting goals and opportunities to travel and help people.   If you are dynamic, goal driven and result minded, this job can be fulfilling and financially rewarding

review_title: A great way of giving back to the community!

job_title: Mortgage Counselor in Kansas City, MO

I had no time left in the day for the buyers under contract. We rarely closed on time. I would get to work at 8:30am and not leave until 10pm because I had so many people to help. I made good money, but finally burned out and had to leave. Great mortgage! Broken process to get it!

pros: I first started working at NACA as a temp in November 2019 and was hired in February 2020 of this year. Especially minorities that often get turned away from other mortgage companies and banks out there. If you're like me, someone that likes to help people from the best of your abilities, then NACA is the place for you. You'll be helping and making someone's dream come true in owning their own home. A life-changing experience that should happen often, but it's not always the case. Besides helping people, there is a lot of great benefits for employees and their families. Health insurances, 41K, etc. If you want to own home yourself, you're more than welcome to go through the process yourself!
cons: Patience, patience, and patience. Got have a lot of it, and it's not necessarily a con. Patience is the key to your success with NACA!

pros:
NACA  has been the biggest leading non-profit/ counseling program around to assist minorities with home ownership. The program allows families to qualify for a mortgage where in the traditional world, most would not qualify. 

I personally fell in-love with the program while at the time going through the program. Initially, I had my doubt but as I continued through the program, I found that it truly was a blessing. 

Because I believed in the NACA's mission, I left my 13 year career as a social worker and became a full-time housing counselor with NACA.  The joy of knowing that I am preparing someone for home ownership is extremely gratifying, 

The program truly offers so much to local communities in the United States. 

It is truly America's mortgage industry  Best Kept Secret
cons: I truly have none.

pros: The company has a great mission.  Because it is a medium-sized nonprofit, many employees receive opportunities and experiences that they would not otherwise receive in the for-profit sector, or even with larger nonprofits.
cons: Management is extremely centralized and very few things can occur without the personal involvement of top company officials.  This corporate control structure makes progressive change very difficult to accomplish.  Moreover, bad ideas -- when they emanate from the top -- are often implemented without any meaningful reflection.

review_title: Great place to work, I liked it so much I came back a second time...
pros: Best mortgage product in America, not just a slogan but a reality.  Benefits are in line with most other mortgage jobs, there is a stable base pay plus commission, no draw pay.  Rapidly growing organization and a streamlined closing process.  We are constantly improving our process and growing the number of people we can help. We are working to make a difference, not just a paycheck. We are changing the world one homeowner at a time. As an employee who started as a temp receptionist in 2008 when the economy collapsed and I couldn't find a job in my previous career path and experience level in Non-Profit Management, I quickly moved to the the role of Mortgage Counselor for 4 years.  In those 4 years I got to travel the country helping tens of thousands of people save their home and simultaneously purchase their first homes when i wasn't on the road.   I was able to help open a new office and relocate to another city.  This was the beginning of my new career path. I left on great terms when I decided i wanted to pursue other career paths, always striving for personal growth.  Only once I was gone did I realize I should have never left.  I came back after 4 years to a larger and expanded role.  The changes that took place in the 4 years I was gone, and continue changing for the better, were amazing.  Not many companies rehire former employees, when I was rehired for a management position I was proud that I was recognized for my previous efforts and feel supported and recognized in my current efforts.  Other pro's are a friendly and dedicated staff and management team that nurture your growth.  Support lines and colleagues that provide daily assistance on a variety of topics is also a strong point.  most jobs you are thrown to the wolves, sink or swim.  At NACA the support structure is there and if you utilize it properly you will be successful. Opportunities for growth and relocation exist but you have to work for them.  They don't hand out promotions unless you have earned them.  all the Management staff have worked their way up to these roles and have served many functions over the years.  One of the most cross trained Management teams I have ever encountered.
cons: Not enough staff to handle the large volume of members that need our help, that's changing as we grow.

review_title: VERY long hours for ridiculously low pay.

However, if you close one mortgage every 2 weeks then you get no paycheck because your commission is paying back the hourly pay.  The problem is that NACA is geared towards people with spotty credit so it can take quite awhile to get someone approved for a mortgage and then get them to closing.  Additionally, if you can't get mortgages closed you will lose your job.

review_title: If the road to Hell is paved with good intentions, NACA must be building a super highway....
pros: NACA has funding commitments from Bank of America and Citibank to provide mortgages to folks who are passed over by the traditional mortgage market (credit-challenged, self-employed, ITIN or undocumented immigrants). They also assist people facing foreclosure or short-sales negotiating a resolution with their lender.
cons: NACA seems to be more interested in getting publicity than running an efficient company. Hyperbole abounds throughout its website, NACA.com and when I first saw it, I thought they were a scam.  The organiztion is hobbled by extensive in-fighting and unprofessional staff. During my six month tenure only two individuals actually got mortgages at my office. The company likes to tout its proprietary software called "Lynx" which is supposed to insure privacy by not allowing any personal documents to be kept in the office - everything is scanned into the "member's" online file and then returned to them. Unfortunately many documents get lost or dissapear into a digital black hole. This is especially frustrating for members who are asked to supply the same documents over and over. A large number of members are Hispanic because NACA is one of the only places ITIN's (undocumented immigrants) can get a mortgage. Unfortunately there is a lack of Spanish speaking counselors and in my office the only bilngual person was the receptionist. This meant we had to rely on members to bring translators who often had English skills that were only slightly better than the person they were translating for. This made discussing complicated topics like mortgages, credit reports, bankruptcies, etc. even more difficult and miscommunication was commonplace. I confronted management regarding this problem a number of times but saw no effort towards improvement.

review_title: You're part of a fight that's taking on systemic racism - it's not going to be easy.
pros:
-NACA is politically on the right side of history. It attracts resilient people and the community is strong. 

-My colleagues are supportive, kind, and helpful.

-NACA is overall a good company; for example, NACA is hiring while everywhere else is laying people off.
cons:
-The hours are excessively long - I barely make minimum wage when I add up all the hours. This really upsets me when I do see what things are being spent on. And this makes me wonder: am I ever going to be able to own a house I see members get? Or pay off my debts? At this job I feel like a 1000th priority. 

-Training is not prioritized. Quality assurance is non-existent. This falls on member services to fix. But a lot of these issues are upstream and need to be addressed way before member services get involved.

-IT efficiency affects everything now that things are digital. And NACA's infrastructure is lacking. 

-Ask counselors/employees frequently what they need.

review_title: Proud to work for an organization the fights for fair terms for current and potential homeowners.
pros: NACA provides workshops to educate the community on what it means to be a homeowner. We review their budget to determine true affordability. This includes potential future repairs. Here at NACA, you are not just a credit score. You are a human being that wants to invest in the stabilization of every community.
cons: NACA has been getting a great response and we need more, quality mortgage counselor that are passionate about turning renters into homeowners.

review_title: Where else can you sincerely help families and have a substantial income?
job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer in Atlanta, GA
pros: No need to door to door sell, motivated buyers, its more than just a mortgage company, its a movement thats been around for 25 years.
cons: Cant work from home, the negative outside opinion doesn't match up with the reality. Naca gets the job done at the end of the day

job_title: Office Administrator in New York, NY
pros:
The joy in helping someone one with low income. Like Social security Income obtain a home is one of the best feeling in the world. Although I am not a counselor. I get to motivate someone who thinks they can't do it. Or want to give up or get to give hope where they feel their is none. Is a joyous experience. 
This position has built me to go in so many directions career wise. I would have never gained this much financial,managerial and community outreach experience no other place..
cons: Lack of communication between departments is ridiculous . We should all be on one accord with the same goal in mind. The quick change in policy with out being aware is so inefficient. Double worked and very unpaid. For some Administrator we run these offices with no reward or bonuses. No annual raises.

review_title: Need to Care More About It's Employees
pros: NACA provides a great learning experience for anyone who wants experience in the industry. The people in the organization are great but there is no appreciation for the work that is being provided by the employees. If you are a "go getter" you have a chance of being successful. The organization helps many people who are struggling paying their mortgages or those who could not image being a homeowner get through the program. It's a rewarding experience to help others who only dreamed of the opportunity to have an affordable payment or a house of their own.
cons: The organization does not treat it's employees well enough to retain them. It is not a company that you can look forward to growing with for the next 5-10+ years. The organization does not provide good training, although they are improving they should do the job of the person that they are training in order to provide the best tools/resources. Every office is treated the same although they are very different. Management care about the staff but are just so overwhelmed wearing multiple hats that they can't focus solely on one need at time, nothing is completed successfully before something else is implemented. The CEO is so concerned about getting funding for organization yet he does not spread the wealth amongst the staff that deserves an increase. Raises rarely happened and in most cases you have to fight to get one. It appears that if you are not extremely outspoken and aggressive (and producing) you will not be heard.

review_title: Not for the faint of heart requires Passion, Integrity, Patience and Perseverance
job_title: Mortgage Loan Officer Aka Mortgage Counselor in Rochester, NY
pros:
Great Mission, Even better Products and Services

Great Co-Workers

More autonomy than other customer facing careers
cons:
My initial perception of the At-Your-Service line was that it would help new employees with any and all questions during a face to face appointment when other office staff is unavailable. The reality is that most of the time all office staff are working and unavailable. When attempting to utilize AYS it was not for that purpose but, for underwriting related questions.

Use of current productivity metrics report does not paint an accurate picture of work completed. Which leads to a loss of passion. 

Lack of constant feedback with regards to policy and procedure content knowledge relates to our current underwriting inconsistencies. My previous experience was at an ISO certified call center than had frequent (monthly) assessments of content knowledge and understanding.
This is helpful to get new hires up to speed.

pros: I enjoyed working for a company that helped people get homes. Without any money down and it does not go by your credit score. The Non profit organizational is really about building communties.

pros:
NACA has annihilated economic injustice by fighting to prove and show that everyone can become  a homeowner.  It takes, advocacy, commitment, hard-work, determination and consistency.  

NACA , there truly is no other.
cons: While the initial process can be overwhelming for some especially for those who have never purchased. NACA is resilient and dedicated to the process of fulfilling the dream of homeownership and Economic justice.  Which includes:  education, counseling and advocacy.   Those that complete the process are rewarded with the best mortgage in America .

pros: The company is really doing a great service to the mortgage industry. It was rewarding to genuinely help people with home ownership.
cons: I was forced to sacrfice personal time (family time) in order to be sure loans closed when usually the issue was held up at a a higher level and out of my control. The system is not streamilined but they will not pay to have more people help and speed things up.

review_title: The most stressful job I've ever had!!
pros: Working for the company, you get the opportunity to travel the country helping homeowners facing foreclosure or those with unaffordable mortgages, save their home by allowing them the opportunity to sit face to face with their lender.
cons: The amount of unnecessary stress created by this place is unbelievable. The management, starting with the CEO, is unorganized. The managers in the offices run things based off of emotions and not performance. There are no opportunities for promotions and there is no such thing as a raise. Also, there is no such thing as personal time or a home life. With the crazy hours and the mandatory 12-14 hour shifts, it is almost impossible to have a life outside of work.

review_title: Inflexible environment much like the army -- while the individual is simply another replaceable cog.
pros: Helps the economically marginalized get access to mortgages.
cons: The use of "mandatory" this and that, was just too much.  The appeal to individuals there is Greed ( "you can make 6-figures...") while the actual motivator afterwards is Fear and Shame. You were expected to work 2 weekends per month "mandatory"; Work late every Thursday (till 7 pm) "mandatory"; You had to account for ALL your time logged on (in 5-minute increments!)

pros: Not everyone gets to wake up in the morning and get paid to do something meaningful.  NACA offers this at all levels of employment.  NACA offers the opportunity for one to make decisions and see them through.
cons: Sometimes it is a lot of work and very emotional to try to help people.

pros: NACA is a great place for someone looking to gain experience as a counselor or in the mortgage industry. My manager has been great at giving me time to review my files and helping me learn. I can’t believe how much she has taught me!

cons: You do have to commit many hours to the organization in order to fight economic justice and help people become homeowners, specially during the weekends.

review_title: Verbally abusive mean and hateful CEO at NACA who daily micromanages and doesn't trust his staff.
pros: Was impressed how NACA make owning a home a reality and possible. When I was verbally insulted for no reason by Bruce I lost all respect for him.
cons: CEO Bruce Marks is verbally abusive and insulting to his staff 24/7/365. Working for Bruce is a nightmare. He will verbally attack and disrespect you at any given time at work. If you are an intelligent, high potential employee he will label you in front of his staff as stupid, dumb and a overall idiot. If you love your family don't come to NACA because you do not get any personal time to spend with them. He will call you on the weekend in the middle of the day and ask you to come to work. He will show up hours later only to check and make sure you reported to work. Friday evenings is another situation where you are leaving work to go home to the family and Bruce will ask you to stay and talk and this is a Friday after work. He does this to make sure you don't leave to go home at a decent time Friday evenings to be with family and kids.

review_title: My experience has been good. I’ve came in unemployed to  now learning about the housing industry.

pros: None, Zero, Nada, No, Ha
cons: Long hours.  Lack of communication , no synergy,  arcadian underwriting system.  Low pay and long hours. Horrible training,  Force to meet with 15 to 20 clients a week. Lofty goals from Supervisors of 10 qualifications a month. Supervisor  often lie and fail to communicate with staff. As a Loan officer, you are force to do work of supervisors and managers in order for loans to close on time. You will have clients with 700 credit scores and it will take a month or more to qualify them due to crazy underwriting criteria.  The most unprofessional work environment you can imagine.  A golden rule while working at any company is not talk about the following 2 topics :  politics,  or religion.  The only thing the local office will talk about is  politics and religion;  in that order! A co worker will throw you under the bus one day and beg you for lunch money or your actual lunch the next day.  Also there was a lack of hygiene in the  building. I put an oil duffisor in my office because a client once complain about the smells coming from another co worker office.  When you leave the company they will try their best not to pay you for the loans that you qualified.  I had inform HR of labor laws to be paid for certain loans. They sent my check as a travel reimbursement,  HR probably didn't want the CEO to find out. The company is composed of over 90 percent of minorities.  While minorities make 90 of the company staff, our white CEO talk down to the company employees constantly on the monthly staff calls. Also the CEO has a photo of Malcolm X in his office, probably to use as a front piece. There more cons but I already wasted enough time on this review.

review_title: CEO is smart enough to do better....
pros: For the most part the counselors and other personnel from the regional level on down were good people. The mission to help their members was admirable, as there is a real need to help people with financial and mortgage counseling.
cons: Working for Mr. Marks, the CEO was like working for Captain Ahab in search of the great white whale. With a dash of Gandhi and a pinch of MLK. It is hard to question his motives and desire to help, but comments about his management style being lacking are spot on, with big questions that are legit regarding his management style. He hires consultants and acts on little regarding making this a good place to work. Micromanagement is his speciality which rolls down through management chain of command, and everything has to have his blessing before being handed down. Hours expectations and workload are extremely  unfair and unmanageable. The complaints are monumental, most are fair assessments of the actual process. It would be a beautiful thing if this could be turned around and the compensation from all sources could be shared with the employees.

pros: The NACA mortgage has the best terms in the industry. For those considering a job here, please read the 'Cons' section.
cons: Extremely unprofessional staff, favoritism, poor communication, retention of the worst employees, toxic work environment from the top down, condescending managers, everyone always looking for a fight, poor benefits, double-standards, sketchy ethical behaviors. If you can work anywhere else, I highly recommend you do so. If you can't work anywhere else, in the mortgage industry or otherwise, try not to become a part of the abusive cycle. Rise above it.

pros: Great Mission, Great Product, Inspirational Work

But after 3-6 months the guaranteed salary goes away and you have to deal with the prospects of being on commission again. However the commissions are extremely small for the amount of work done on each file ($300-$500)
